data.title: Luke Ridnour Talks / Bob Sansevere Listens
data.meta_description: My proudest moment as an athlete was winning our first state championship in high school. We won two. data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

My proudest moment as an athlete was winning our first state championship in high school. We won two. We lost my sophomore year in the state finals and won in my junior and senior year. It was fun because my school was so small (in Blaine, Wash.). All the kids I grew up with since first grade were on the same team. It was the first state title in school history. So for us to win it was pretty cool.

I stay in touch with all of them. I was the point guard, but I was one of the taller ones, so I did a little bit of everything.

It’s never fun to lose. For me, it’s not until I get home and see my family that there’s perspective. You get to see your little guys running around, and they don’t care if you won or lost.

I have three kids – all boys. They’re 2-1/2 years old and 11 months old. The twins are 11 months. It’s tough when you have twins and a 2-1/2 year old. They keep you busy. And we’re definitely in diaper mode.

I got married at 24. I met her when I was 20. We met when I was in college. I just knew she was the one when I saw her.

I’m a nice guy.

Besides basketball, I played tennis and baseball in high school. In baseball, I did a little bit of everything. Outfield. Infield. We were a small school, so I was all over the place. I tried pitching, but my arm was so bad.

My parents had a big influence on my life. They got me involved in sports.

Worst thing I did as a kid? We used to egg houses every weekend. It was nobody’s house in particular. We just liked to egg people.

When I was a kid, I wanted to grow up to be a basketball player.

If I had a time machine, I’d like to go back to when Christ was alive. I’d want to be with him.

Favorite cartoon growing up? “Transformers.” I liked the movies, too.

Favorite cereal? Froot Loops.

If I could have any superpower, I’d want to be like Spiderman and go building to building.

Funniest movie ever made? That’s a hard question. I like “Old School.” I like “Happy Gilmore.” What else is a classic? “Christmas Vacation.” That’s a classic.

My favorite movie is “Braveheart.”

I don’t have a favorite actor or actress.

Pet peeve? Loud, chewing of gum. People that chomp.

I’m a steak and potatoes guy.

The toughest part about being a pro basketball player is being away from the family. It’s just so much fun being around them. They don’t really understand why you’re gone.

I want to be known as a good player, a good teammate. More importantly, I just want to be known as a man of God – someone who serves the Lord and plays for him and not myself.

My reaction to J.J. Barea joining us? You know, I’m been around long enough that whatever happens, I don’t really worry about it. I’m going to just come and compete. He’s a good player, so whatever can help our team, I’m in.

I’ve got a feeling it’s going to turn around pretty soon (for the Timberwolves).

I don’t really have a prized possession. No material things, really.

Best book I ever read? “When Heaven Invades Earth.”

I don’t have time for video games.

My idea of a perfect day is being with the family and just hanging with them. My kids love being outside, so just being outside would be fine.

My teammates would be surprised to know that I got third in the state in tennis. I did it my senior year. I still play tennis in the offseason. I never really played much. It just came kind of natural. It was fun.

I’m big into worship music. I like a band called “Jesus Culture.”

There’s no time for TV any more. I used to like “The Office.”

The TV usually is on PBS and the Disney Channel now.

I wouldn’t change anything about my life. I don’t regret anything.

The best advice I ever got was to forget what happened and keep going.

I’m sure I’ve gotten bad advice, but nothing comes to mind.

If I could trade places for a day with anyone, I’d like to be a pro tennis player for a day. I’d pick an American. Andy Roddick. Just to be on the tour would be fun.

I want my epitaph to say, “Here lies Luke Ridnour, a man of God who served the Lord and put Him first in everything he did.”

Bob Sansevere can be reached at bsansevere@pioneerpress.com.

Originally Published: January 16, 2012 at 11:01 p.m.
